Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Malice was jolted awake from Campflage's sream, and fell off his bed with a very loud thud.  He picked himself up off the floor and stood up too fast, stumbled a second, then went out the door.  He went looking for Camoflage, but was unsucessful.  He then found Wolfblade fast asleep at a work bench.  He picked her up and took her to his quarters.  He set he on the bed and retrieved the generator she was working on.  He set it on the night stand, and went to the cargo bay.  He found a cargo net strong enough to support his weight.  He took it back to his quarters, string it up as a hammock, grabbed the alarm clock, climbed into the hammock, hit the lights, and went to sleep.


shadowess_azogoth <shadowess_azogoth@...> wrote:Wolfblade:
She yawned and kept working.  Her energy levels were dropping and she 
would need to sleep soon. Still, she faught it off and kept working. 
After a bit, she went to the other bench and grabbed a stool to sit 
on. She sat down and kept working. In a few hours, she was leaning 
over the magnet, sound asleep. 


--- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, robert riley <bustercross365@y...> 
wrote:
> Malice yawned and patted Wolfblade on her shoulder.
> "See you in a few cycles.  If you do get tired, talk to Kup or 
someone, they should set you up with a room.  Goodnight."
> Malice walked down some halls and found his way to his temporary 
quarters.  He opened the door and stepped in.  He sat down on the 
edge of the bed, and sat quiet for a moment.  then he pulled the 
energon storage and put it on top of the locker.  He opened the 
locker and snapped off another chunk of energon.  He leaned back on 
the bed, crunching on the energon.  He finished it, found an alarm 
clock, set it, and went to sleep.
> 
> shadowess_azogoth <shadowess_azogoth@y...> wrote:
> Wolfblade::
> 
> She worked trying to put together the magnet and improve it to work 
> for it's purpose. "No thanks. I'm not tired. I have work to do."Her 
> voice was short and curt.  She then looked up at Malice and said in 
a 
> softer tone, "I can't blame you. I'd have done the same thing. I 
> wouldn't admit it though."  She looked back at the table and 
resumed 
> her work. 
> 
>
